column4: Hi everyone. I'm new to Ubuntu, and I was wondering what the best way to install it would be for me - I want a persistent install which runs speedily (IE not in something like virtualbox) and without installing it too deeply in my system to begin with - I run Windows 7 at the moment. Thanks.
what does "not to deeply means" in this context?
Basically I want to be able to easily remove it if I need to - it seems a lot of installs require formatting of drives and allocating permanent space on a drive
hm, maybe wubi is an option for you, which you can later transform into a stand-alone system
you can use a usb-drive
Oh, indeed, I just read that - how much space does it take?
700mb
Oh, that's good
Also, I see it recommends the 32-bit edition. Why is that? Wouldn't the 64 be faster?
64bit doesnt mean faster
and i dont know why 32bit should be recommend? who said that?
The website - 32-bit - Recommended for most users 64-bit - Not recommended for daily desktop usage
But wouldn't 64-bit utilize more memory?
dont know why, sorry
yes 64bit is using more then 4gb ram ad working fine here on my lucid-installation
with 4gb ram you need 64bit version
That's what I was thinking, I have 64 bit on windows. Was just curious as to why the website advises 32 bit.
64bit
dont use 32bit and dont use pae
pae?
linxeh: Ok, thanks, I'll go for 64-bit :)
